Fed set to hold rates steady as Middle East crisis, tariffs cloud outlook

June 18, 2025
  • Fed to maintain 4.25%-4.50% interest rate.
  • Tariffs may increase inflation, economists warn.
  • Middle East crisis spikes oil prices.
  • One rate cut expected by September 2025.
  • Powell’s press conference to provide policy clues.
The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its benchmark interest rate at 4.25%-4.50% on June 18, 2025, as policymakers navigate economic uncertainties driven by U.S. import tariffs and escalating Middle East tensions. Since December 2024, the Fed has adopted a cautious stance, with Chair Jerome Powell emphasizing the need for clarity on tariff impacts, which could raise inflation, according to Reuters. The Middle East crisis, particularly Israel’s recent strikes on Iran, has spiked oil prices, further complicating the inflation outlook. Fed projections, due at 2 p.m. EDT, are expected to show one rate cut by September 2025, per posts on X. Trump’s tariff policies, implemented since January 2025, have increased costs for businesses, with some absorbing expenses to avoid consumer price hikes, as noted by RBC Brewin Dolphin. This has led to a cloudy economic forecast, with retail sales slipping as consumers grow cautious. Additional research suggests tariffs could reduce U.S. GDP growth by 0.5% in 2025, per economic models. Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari has warned against ignoring tariff-driven inflation, advocating for steady rates. The Fed’s decision comes amid speculation about Powell’s successor, adding to market uncertainty. Investors anticipate no immediate rate changes, with focus on Powell’s press conference for hints of future policy shifts.

Sources

  • Fed set to hold rates steady as Middle East crisis, tariffs cloud outlook
  • Markets calm despite conflict in the Middle East
  • Feds Kashkari calls for steady rates
